newsitem.title: USA: SEC calls press report of Levitt fundraising silly.
newsitem.headline: SEC calls press report of Levitt fundraising silly.

text.p: A Securities and Exchange Commission spokesman on Wednesday tossed off as "nonsense" a press report about political fundraising activities by Chairman Arthur Levitt before he was appointed to head the agency.
"The bottom line is that this is nonsense, and we are not even going to dignify it with a response," Chris Ullman, SEC director of public affairs, said in a telephone interview.

He was responding to a report in The Bond Buyer Wednesday that Levitt was one of several "leading national fundraisers" for the Democratic party during the 1992 election who was "interested in serving" in the Clinton administration, according to documents released this week by the Democratic National Committee (DNC).

The paper said that the documents include a Dec. 21, 1992 memo from two DNC employees to the former deputy director of then President-elect Bill Clinton's transition team, listing Levitt as a "must consider" for five administration posts, including ambassadorships to Germany or Mexico.
The paper said it is not clear whether Levitt actively sought the administration posts.

The story raised eyebrows on Wall Street on Wednesday because Levitt has launched an aggressive campaign to eliminate "pay-to-play" - or the giving of political contibutions in return for bond business - in the muni arena.

Wall Street bond firms signed a voluntary ban on pay-to-play in their sector several years ago and the Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board issued a rule restricting the practice by dealers soon after.
Levitt has criticized bond lawyers for not developing a voluntary ban on the practice.
Paul Maco, head of SEC's Office of Municipal Securities, said "there's no comparison" between Levitt's fundraising activities and pay-to-play.

"Any inference to the contrary is simply another effort to cloud the issues surrounding pay-to-play. One is open and disclosed political support for a candidate for public office followed by public service in public office after the merits of the appointment have been reviewed and confirmed by the U.S. Senate," Maco said.

"The other is the often hidden making of political contributions to override considerations of merit - quality, experience and competence - to get local government securities business and calling into question the integrity of the municipal securities market," Maco added.
Howard Zucker, who chairs the public finance committee of the American Bar Association's state and local governments section, said he had no comment.
